posts.name: Issueseverywhere
posts.cooked:
Hi,

It seems weird that Signal still relies on GCM/FCM for notifications.

Even with Signal APK downloaded from the website, and having whitelisted Signal in DNSfilter (personalDNSfilter | F-Droid - Free and Open Source Android App Repository), I can’t receive Signal notifications if I do not open the app, because I blocked GCM/FCM adresses (mtalk.google.com, alt1-mtalk.google.com,…) with DNSfilter.

While we trust Signal for keeping the minimum metadata, how can we know what Google keeps if Signal needs to transmit data to their servers for each notification/message ?

Furthermore, curcumventing GCM/FCM has been solved by other android app team, like Tutanota (the blog post also cites Mastodon):

f-droid.org

How Tutanota replaced Google’s FCM with their own notification system |...

As mentioned in This Week In F-Droid 17,Tutanota is now on F-Droid.In this special post Ivanfrom Tutanota, tells us the story.Hi, I’m Ivan and I am developin...

Is there a plan to drop GCM/FCM (which as Tutanota highlights “includes Google’s tracking code for analytics purposes”) for SSE (Server Sent Events API) or another alternative ?

Thanks

link_counts.title: How Tutanota replaced Google’s FCM with their own notification system | F-Droid - Free and Open Source Android App Repository
DNSfilter | F-Droid - Free and Open Source Android App Repository

posts.cooked:
issueseverywhere:

Even with Signal APK downloaded from the website, and having whitelisted Signal in DNSfilter (personalDNSfilter | F-Droid - Free and Open Source Android App Repository), I can’t receive Signal notifications if I do not open the app, because I blocked GCM/FCM adresses (mtalk.google.com, alt1-mtalk.google.com,…) with DNSfilter.

You have to deactivate the google play service before you install signal the first time. Then signal detects that it has to run in GCM/FCM-free mode.

issueseverywhere:

While we trust Signal for keeping the minimum metadata, how can we know what Google keeps if Signal needs to transmit data to their servers for each notification/message ?

Google does not get any metadata from signal. GCM/FCM is only used to wakeup Signal on the phone. Signal then connects strait to the server and gets the messages.

link_counts.title: Why am I being forced to use Google Play Services?

posts.name: ⚠️ abandoned account ⚠️
posts.cooked:
issueseverywhere:

It seems weird that Signal still relies on GCM/FCM for notifications.

Signal relies on gcm/fcm ONLY if gcm/fcm is “present” during the (first) registration. And this has already been discussed here several times. imo, it’s kind of weird to complain about Signal using fcm/gcm when those are installed.

Damn, I can’t find the links to the discussions about tutanota/k9mail solutions. Maybe it was even another forum I’m getting older

Therefore, Signal also does not include any tracker as listed e.g. here:
https://reports.exodus-privacy.eu.org/en/reports/search/org.thoughtcrime.securesms/

posts.name: Kee Jefferys
posts.cooked:
Yes, Google needs to know your IP address to be able to Push notifications to your phone, They likely already know this though, unless your using some sort of de-googled Android phone.

On Session you can use only background notifications, they wont be very reliable but you dont have to deal with FCM unless you opt in
It would be nice using a fallback behaviour to GMS alternatives when they aren’t installed, like UnifiedPush or openpush

link_counts.title: OpenPush - A Free, Decentralized Push Messaging Framework for Android | F-Droid - Free and Open Source Android App Repository

posts.cooked:
I wish Signal allows me choose my distributor for Push Notifications. (e.g. so that I can use Gotify instead of FCM / Google services)

UnifiedPush is a recent FOSS library that allows this, I suggest to include it in Signal.

See https://unifiedpush.org and Matrix discussion #unifiedpush:matrix.org

OpenPush - A Free, Decentralized Push Messaging Framework

A Google Cloud Messaging (GCM) /Firebase Cloud Messaging (FCM) REPLACEMENT

OpenPush is a self-hosted, free alternative push messaging implementation which can either run alongside or as a replacement to FCM.
OpenPush was presented at FOSDEM. The talk gives a general architecture overview as well as walks through the design and implementation challenges of a push messaging service.
OpenPush Article more links in article
https://f-droid.org/en/2020/02/03/openpush-talk.html
OpenPush Project Website

bubu1.eu

bubu1.eu

posts.name: definitely not clickbait
posts.cooked: just give us setting to switch off google notifications for those who are trying to degoogle their phones… why would i degoogle my phone if i losr all messages and grouo chats??

definitely_not_click:

why would i degoogle my phone if i losr all messages and grouo chats??

Why would you lose all messages? The Android client has backups.

posts.name: Stephen R
posts.cooked:
lagapi:

It would be nice using a fallback behaviour to GMS alternatives when they aren’t installed, like UnifiedPush

A big upvote for Unified Push (UP) support. Signal is very popular among the “degoogle/privacy” community, and UP support would be a boon to our collective battery life. Also a project as big as Signal supporting UP would be a boon for UP – which is deserving of the support. There’s a definite “network effect” at play with Unified Push, in that the more apps that support it, the more useful it becomes.

FOSS Signal app could offer a user option on notifications:

  • FCM
  • Unified Push
  • whatever it uses now when FCM isn’t there (persistent connection?)

OR, it could just do a cascade:

Is FCM present? Use FCM. If not…
Is UP present? Use UP. If not…
Do whatever you do currently when FCM isn’t present.

NOTE: OpenPush is discontinued and completely supplanted by Unified Push. UP is a more flexible system.

link_counts.title: Severe 'notification issue', please implement suggested workarounds

posts.name: Stephen R
posts.cooked:
minnmann:

This analytic/telemetry code is disabled in Signal

That may be, but to use Google notifications I still have to turn them on, which likely enables that tracking in any number of other apps that didn’t think to explicitly turn it off. (I mean… good on you for deactivating the tracking. But even better is an alternative that doesn’t touch Google at all. )

posts.name: Christophe Henry
posts.cooked:
As you are aware, since API level 26 (Android 8.0), Android has restricted the ability for apps to execute in the background and, therefore, to fetch new message for instant message apps. Google has implemented FCL to let these apps receive notifications but that won’t work on AOSP or microG.

UnifiedPush is a protocol that aims to fill the gap on these platforms and is starting to be adopted by several other competitors like Element

I’d really love to have that on Signal.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: Signal already has a method of getting messages without Play Services and it doesn’t really consume that much power at all.

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked:
christophehenry:

UnifiedPush is a protocol that aims to fill the gap on these platforms

Doesn’t that move the trust issue from Google to those running the Unifiedpush servers?

posts.name: Christophe Henry
posts.cooked:
Some some UnifiedPush solutions like ntfy.sh can be self hosted, which is what I already do for Element and Fedilab.

@Whatnoww Yes but it’s not just about Signal. Nowadays it’s not unusual to have 3 or 4 apps that have their own notification to execute in the background. Each app drains battery and pollutes notifications doing so.

But now that an alternative standard exists, why not adopt it?

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: An alternative standard existing on it’s own is not a sufficient enough reason to support it, especially not when a minority of users will use it.

posts.name: Christophe Henry
posts.cooked:
As I said: it’s been adopted by several competitors, most notably Matrix (Element). So not exactly just “existing on its own”.

But I agree, a minority of users will use it. But a minority a users have phones without gapps anyway. Does that mean we should be disregarded? If yes, why does this topic exist anyway?

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: Chinese users aren’t a small userbase.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: Signal doesn’t constantly run in the background so these are likely the system reporting incorrectly.
